2,Contacts,,,,1,"Bulk Update GDPR Subscriptions, Double-Opt-In to the Contacts Table View",,,,,"

What is it?

We have added support for bulk updating GDPR subscription status, and double-opt-in status for contacts on the contacts view.

Why does it matter?

The historical way of updating contacts via import caused a ton of friction for our customers. They would need to export contacts, manipulate them in excel, and then re-import them with different values. Additionally, the import flow did not support the robustness required of GDPR subscriptions. This new placement will both meet the needs of our users and allow our product teams to remain flexible for changes to subscriptions. Our users can still update subscriptions in bulk via the contacts view.

How does it work?

Simply create a filter on the contacts board of contacts who need their status updated, click the “more” dropdown - and you’re on your way. View this knowledge document here for more information.

Who gets it?

Any portal with GDPR or Double-Opt-In enabled will see this in the ‘more’ dropdown of their contacts view.

Please note - this does remove the ability to update a contact’s subscription status via the import tool.

Source: Product Notifications

2,Contacts,,,,21,"See ""Secondary"" Email/Domain for Merged Contacts/Companies",,,,,"

What is it
The ability to see previous email addresses for merged contacts and previous company domains for merged companies.
As your database grows, keeping it clean gets a whole lot harder. With the goal of keeping your systems dupe-free, with a recent update, you can now merge contacts and companies.

But when you merge records, it’s important not to lose sight of the record that existed before. Before today’s change, tracking down the email address (for merged contacts) or company domain (for merged companies) required digging into the property change history. With today’s change, those data points are a whole lot easier to track down.

Merge one contact into another. Then, find the email address property of the single remaining contact, and you’ll see both email addresses. The first one listed is the “primary,” and will be emailed whenever this contact is included in a send. The second is “secondary.” It’s visible, but at this time doesn’t play into any other functionality within the record.
Merge one company into another. Then, find the “Company Domain Name” property in the remaining record. You’ll see both domains listed:

What is it?

Now live is the ability for a company in your HubSpot CRM to be associated with a child company and a parent company.

Why it matters?

One of the fundamental needs of a CRM is that it reflects the reality of your business. That you can structure your database in the CRM in the same way that your customers are structured. This is why associating two companies together within a “parent-child” relationship is so important.

However, it was only possible to associated companies in one level of parent-child before. A company could either have a parent, or it could have a child. It was not possible to set up multiple levels. Now, companies can have both a parent and a child.

How it works?

  • Navigate to any company in HubSpot CRM that you’d like to relate to another company

  • Within the company record, scroll down to the “Related Companies” card

• Choose to add a child company or a parent company, then search for and select the company you want to associate.

  • Once you’ve saved the association, you’ll see the relationship in the “Related Companies” card on your company record.

  • If you’ve added a parent company, you’ll have a link to the parent company within the record and the ability to quickly see the other child companies of that same organization.

  • If you’ve added a child company, you’ll see links to the other child companies within the record, with the ability to add another child company as well.

The above update is now available to all HubSpot users and available in all languages supported by HubSpot.

Source: Product Notifications

What is it?
The ability to relate two companies to each other in HubSpot CRM, “parent-child” style.

Companies across all industries run into organizational issues with their company databases --- whether franchises, distributors, school branches, or anything else. With today’s release, you can link companies in your database to one another other with just a few clicks. The new function enables you to navigate between related companies quickly and easily, saving you time and unnecessary headache.
Navigate to any company in HubSpot CRM that you’d like to relate to another company.
Within the company record, scroll down to the “Related Companies” card.
Choose to add a child company or a parent company, then search for and select the company you want to associate.
Once you’ve saved the association, you’ll see the relationship in the “Related Companies” card on your company record.
If you’ve added a parent company, you’ll have a link to the parent company and the ability to quickly see the other child companies of that same organization.
If you’ve added a child company, you’ll see links to the other child companies, with the ability to add another child company as well.
A few important notes on the functionality, as it stands today:
• Along with the company-level functionality, there are two new properties that can be used for view segmentation: Number of Child Companies and Parent Company.
• Salesforce-integrated portals can use the function in HubSpot, but parent-child associations won't sync from HubSpot to Salesforce.
• Customers can create a single level of parent-child hierarchy.
• Parent companies can have more than one child.
• Child companies can't be attached to more than one parent.
• Companies can have a maximum of 10,000 children.
• It is not possible to import companies to a parent-child relationship
• The public API to connect companies in a parent-child relationship will be released once this feature is out of beta.
All HubSpot CRM portals will get parent-child.
The parent-child widget will inherit the language chosen in the portal's settings

What it is
The ability to opt company domains out of automatic creation and association in HubSpot CRM.
In HubSpot CRM, users can enable the auto-creation of companies.

If this setting is enabled, when a contact is created, HubSpot looks at its email address, checks to see whether a company already exists for that domain, and creates a new one (and associates the two records) if it doesn’t find one. For example, if you add a contact with the email address sophie@hubspot.com, HubSpot will search your database for companies with the domain ""hubspot.com.” If one exists, Sophie’s contact will be automatically associated with it. If one does not exist, a new company will be created. This is a powerful feature and a huge time-saver: just by creating a single contact, the company record is automatically created and enriched, and associated to the contact.

But, even if this setting is enabled, you don’t necessarily want a company to be auto-created for every contact you create. If you were to add andy@gmail.com or marc@comcast.net to your database, chances are that you don’t need Gmail and Comcast created as companies. With that in mind, behind the scenes, HubSpot keeps a “blacklist” of companies that we do not auto-create companies for. This saves you the hassle of cleaning up unwanted companies from your database.

While the HubSpot list goes a long way towards keeping your company list neat and tidy, we want to give you, our users, even more power over the cleanliness of your database. With today’s change, you now have the ability to opt company domains out of automatic creation and association to ensure they don’t get created each and every time a new contact from their domain is added to your database.

• Add the secondary domain of a company. For example, if contacts at Coke had emails under “cocacola.com,” “coke.com,” and “coke.net,” you might only want a ""Coke"" to exist as a company in your database. In that case, opt out “coke.com” and “coke.net” to ensure that companies don’t get created for those domains moving forward.

Navigate to Settings > Companies. Find the setting for “Automatically create and associate companies with contacts.” If it’s checked, read on. If not, read through this help doc to decide if the setting is a fit for your team’s process.
If the setting is enabled, you’ll see a brand new link below: “Opt a domain out of automatic associations:”

What is it:

You can now customize the info your team collects when deals move from stage to stage in HubSpot CRM. As an added bonus, you can require certain properties to be completed in order for a deal to move to a specific stage.

As a sales leader, you need consistent data at every point in your sales process. The more consistent your data, the more predictable your outcomes, and the better you’ll be able to forecast your month, qualify your deals, and coach your reps. But in order to have consistent data, your team needs to have a consistent process.

With that goal in mind, with today’s update, you can ensure that all your reps are collecting the same information as they move deals through the pipeline. And, for those datapoints that are absolutely critical, you can require those properties to be completed before a deal jumps stages.
Navigate to Settings > Deals, and you’ll see a flashy new message pointing you in the right direction:
Click “Add Properties” under the new “Update Stage Properties” column, for the stage you’d like to set required properties for. When you do, you’ll come to this:

Check off the properties you’d like reps to see when they move deals into that stage on the left-hand side. If you’d like some of those properties to be required, simply select the “Required” column on the right. Once, you’re done, save the changes.
Next time a rep is moving a deal to that stage, they’ll see a quick modal asking them to fill out the properties you set up:
• The stage change properties aren’t cumulative. In other words, if a deal skips from stage 1 to stage 3, you won’t be required to complete the properties for stage 2.
• The properties you configure for deal stage changes are portal-wide.
• If a property is already filled in, the value will prepopulate in the modal above. No need to give properties a new value every time.
• Only users with access to settings (e.g. admins) will be able to update these settings.

What it is:
Five new tools in your task management toolbelt: a significant new productivity feature called task queues, and four smaller improvements.
Not pumped yet? Watch this video, share it on LinkedIn and Twitter, then keep reading:

We’ve let one critical component of HubSpot CRM collect dust for far too long: task management. If you (or one of your prospects/clients) use HubSpot CRM, you’ll agree with us: Tasks in HubSpot have been adequate, but not exceptional. They’re like eating iceberg lettuce. Not the end of the world, but not mind-blowingly awesome either.

Today, that changes. Task management in HubSpot has a slew of new functionality. Staying on top of to-dos is pivotal to a sales team’s success. Every missed follow-up is a lost chance at a connection with your prospects and customers. With HubSpot’s new Tasks interface, our customers will never let a follow-up slip through the cracks.

• Get more done in fewer clicks. Time spent fumbling around to manage follow-ups is time spent away from selling. In a world in which salespeople spend only 30% of their time actually selling, every second saved means more deals closed.

    Imagine a world in which you never had to leave your to-do list, in which you never had to manually schedule your next follow-up, in which you never had to click into a CRM record to figure out what to do next. With the new tasks interface, that world has arrived. Your sales team’s productivity will increase exponentially using tasks in HubSpot CRM, because they’ll stick to what they do best: selling.
<li>Ditch distractions. Don’t get overwhelmed. Focused sales reps are productive sales reps. With task queues, your team won’t need to open dozens of tabs at the beginning of the day
column2: they won’t need to sort through pages of to-do’s at a time
column3: they won’t need to scroll a million ways to get to the next thing. Walk into work. Build your task queue. Press play. Run through your tasks. Go home. Rinse, wash, repeat.

column1: • Always have your next steps in order. 80% of sales require 5 follow-up phone calls after the meeting, yet 44% of salespeople give up after one follow-up. Don’t be a part of the 44%. What is it?
Goals, a feature that was released in beta at INBOUND, is now fully live and available to all Sales Hub Starter, Professional, and Enterprise users as well as all Service Hub Enterprise users.

Why does it matter?

We introduced “Goals” as a new variation of quota management. “Quota” is a term that has traditionally been associated with sales, but the idea of giving an individual a goal and helping them track toward that goal extends outside the realm of sales. In fact, these goals can come in all shapes and sizes: calls made, meetings booked, revenue won, tickets closed… the list goes on.

How does it work?

Today, Sales Hub Starter and Sales Hub Professional portals get access to basic goals.

Sales Hub Enterprise and Service Hub Enterprise portals get access to advanced goals:

  • For Sales Hub Enterprise, Managers can assign one of four types of Goals: Revenue per rep, Meetings per rep, Calls per rep, Deals created per rep. Goals can be set on a monthly basis, and goals for a given time period will be stored historically.

• For Service Hub Enterprise, Managers can assign one of three types of Goals: Tickets closed by agent, Average Resolution Time by agent, and Average Response Time by agent. Goals can be set on a monthly basis, and goals for a given time period will be stored historically.

As a reminder for how we’ve approached the transition from “Quotas” to “Goals”, check out this product notification from August.

What is it?

The ability to import multiple objects at once, and associate them with each other automatically upon import --- rather than manually, after the fact --- in HubSpot CRM.

Why does it matter?

When managing records in any CRM, objects don’t exist in a vacuum
column2:
they’re connected. Having John Smith as a contact in your database is great, and having his company (Acmecorp) on file is great too. Have a sales opportunity at Acmecorp? Even better. But the power of CRM doesn’t truly come to life until the connections between those three things are made. Associating records to each other enables you unlock the power of their shared context: see all the interactions between Acmecorp contacts and your company on a single timeline, run deal reports based on original contact source, and more.

Up till now, making connections between objects in HubSpot CRM has been manual. Navigate to a contact, click the “deals” card, track down the right deal, associate it, and so on. One association takes just a few seconds. But imagine thousands. Or even millions. Put another way, put yourself in the shoes of a company getting started with HubSpot. You’ve just signed up for our software, and *surprise!*  your first task is to import a slew of data from your old system, then manually wade through it for weeks to associate objects. Or, if you’d rather, you can pay a third party that you’ve never heard of hundreds of dollars to do the deed on your behalf. Not the best way to get started with a new software platform….

With today’s change, associating records from different objects isn’t just easy
column3:
it’s automatic. No more manual slog when getting started with HubSpot. No third party bills to pay. Just your data, in HubSpot.

How does it work?This is where it gets fun.

Preparing your data

The first step in associating two objects via import is creating a separate spreadsheet for each, and ensuring there’s a common column across the sheets. This column will be used to identify the objects which need to be associated.  

In the below example, we have a column for “Deal ID” on our contacts sheet. This way, deals will be associated with their matching contact.

A few nitty-gritty technical notes:

  • If you upload files for existing contacts or companies, any existing information will be overwritten by new values you’ve imported.

  • Contacts are deduplicated by email address

  • Companies are deduplicated by company domain name

  • If you are using this feature to explicitly associate contacts and companies - you must first disable the feature that associates companies and contacts.

If you’re looking to associate multiple records of one object type to a single record of another,  one of your objects must contain a unique value for the other to reference. In the below example, Deal ID (stored on deals) is the unique value, and if two contacts are associated with one deal, they may share a deal ID. In the below example, “Deal Three” will have 2 contacts associated with it - Brian Halligan and Dharmesh Shah.

Running the import:

Step 1: Start your import and choose “multiple objects with associations”

Step 2: Select the two objects you’re importing.

Step 3: Upload your files (.csv, .xls, .xlsx supported)

column1:
Step 4: Select the column that links your two files together. Note: the column headers must match exactly in order to make associations.

Step 5: Define which object the common column belongs to. This unique key must be unique in the file so that HubSpot can make the appropriate associations.

Step 6: Map your properties for both objects.

Step 7: Sit back, relax, and watch your data peruse into your portal.

Which objects are available today?

Contacts, companies, deals, and tickets. Not engagements or products/line items --- yet. We’re aware that these are in high demand, and are considering them moving forward.

Who gets it?

Eventually, all HubSpot portals --- free through Enterprise, across all hubs.

Today, only a small hand-selected group of beta portals, including those who voiced their opinions on the community. Have a customer who might be interested? Fill out the form on their behalf, and we’ll consider them for the beta. Note that for the first few weeks, we’ll be letting portals in slowly and selectively
column2:
we want to ensure that the new infrastructure holds up under increased volume, and across every use case. With that in mind, set customer expectations accordingly, and don’t ping Dylan or I if it’s been a day or two, and the portal doesn’t yet have access.

Want to test it out for yourself?

Great. It’s already in your portal. You’ll find three spreadsheets attached to this email --- a sample spreadsheet each of contacts, companies, and deals. Go crazy!

What languages is it available in?

All languages that the HubSpot product is translated into.

Source: Product Notifications
